FLeNS: Federated Learning with Enhanced Nesterov-Newton Sketch

Abstract

Federated learning faces a critical challenge in balancing communication efficiency with rapid convergence, especially for second-order methods. While Newton-type algorithms achieve linear convergence in communication rounds, transmitting full Hessian matrices is often impractical due to quadratic complexity. We introduce Federated Learning with Enhanced Nesterov-Newton Sketch (FLeNS), a novel method that harnesses both the acceleration capabilities of Nesterov’s method and the dimensionality reduction benefits of Hessian sketching. FLeNS approximates the centralized Newton’s method without relying on the exact Hessian, significantly reducing communication overhead. By combining Nesterov’s acceleration with adaptive Hessian sketching, FLeNS preserves crucial second-order information while preserving the rapid convergence characteristics. Our theoretical analysis, grounded in statistical learning, demonstrates that FLeNS achieves super-linear convergence rates in communication rounds - a notable advancement in federated optimization. We provide rigorous convergence guarantees and characterize tradeoffs between acceleration, sketch size, and convergence speed. Extensive empirical evaluation validates our theoretical findings, showcasing FLeNS’s state-of-the-art performance with reduced communication requirements, particularly in privacy-sensitive and edge-computing scenarios. The code is available at https://github.com/sunnyinAI/FLeNS

Index Terms:
Federated Learning, Machine Learning, Distributed, Parallel, and Cluster Computing

I Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as an up-and-coming framework for large-scale machine learning tasks, by providing substantial benefits in terms of privacy protection and computational efficiency [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]. By enabling decentralized model training without sharing raw data, FL addresses concerns of data sensitivity and ownership. However, a significant challenge in FL is balancing the tradeoff between fast convergence rates and minimizing communication overhead.

First-order optimization methods, such as FedAvg [2] and FedProx [3], have been widely adopted in FL due to their efficiency in communicating only gradient information, thus preserving data privacy while handling heterogeneous data distributions. Despite their success, these methods exhibit slow convergence rates, typically achieving only sublinear convergence, O​(1/t)𝑂1𝑡O(1/t), where t𝑡t represents communication rounds [6, 7, 8]. Recent advances in convergence analysis [3, 7, 8, 9] and generalization bounds [10, 5, 11, 12] have solidified the theoretical foundations of these approaches. However, the inherent limitations of first-order methods in terms of slow convergence continue to pose significant challenges for complex, high-dimensional problems.

In contrast, second-order methods, such as Newton’s method, are known for their superior convergence rates in centralized settings, often achieving linear or super-linear convergence under mild conditions [13, 14]. However, directly applying these methods in FL is impractical due to the high communication costs associated with transmitting local Hessian matrices. Various approximations, including BFGS [15], L-BFGS [16], inexact Newton [17], Gauss-Newton [18] and Newton sketch [19], have been proposed to mitigate computational complexity, but adapting them to FL while maintaining communication efficiency remains a challenge.

In this paper, we propose FLeNS (Federated Learning with Enhanced Nesterov-Newton Sketch), a novel optimization algorithm that harnesses the acceleration capabilities of Nesterov’s method [20] and the dimensionality reduction benefits of Hessian sketching [19]. FLeNS efficiently approximates Newton’s method while significantly reducing communication complexity by leveraging adaptive Hessian sketching, which reduces the sketch size to the effective dimension of the Hessian matrix. This innovative approach addresses the key challenges of federated learning—ensuring fast convergence, reducing computational burden, and minimizing communication costs, all while maintaining robust generalization performance. FLeNS makes several key contributions to federated optimization:

On the algorithmic front: FLeNS introduces a second-order federated optimization algorithm that integrates Nesterov’s acceleration with sketched Hessians to achieve superlinear convergence which effectively reduces the communication complexity, making it scalable in real-world federated environments.

On the statistical front: FLeNS offers a rigorous theoretical framework that guarantees both convergence speed and communication efficiency. This balance enables the algorithm to scale well with large datasets without compromising accuracy ensuring that superlinear convergence can be maintained with minimal communication overhead.

II Related Work

In Federated Learning (FL), methods like FedAvg [2] and FedProx [3] are widely used due to their simplicity and communication efficiency. These algorithms only transmit local gradients of size M𝑀M, where M𝑀M is the dimension of the feature space, resulting in a communication complexity of O​(M)𝑂𝑀O(M). The convergence properties of FedAvg and FedProx have been thoroughly analyzed in [6], with an iteration complexity of T=O​(1/δ)𝑇𝑂1𝛿T=O(1/\delta) required to obtain a δ𝛿\delta-accurate solution. However, the sublinear convergence rates of these methods pose significant challenges for large-scale, high-dimensional problems, especially when dealing with non-i.i.d. data distributions across clients.

To accelerate convergence, Newton Sketch [19] was introduced as a second-order method that approximates Newton’s method using sketching techniques to reduce computational and communication burdens. Newton Sketching has been further optimized by methods such as Newton-LESS [21, 22, 23] reducing the effective dimension of the Hessian matrix, reducing communication complexity from O​(M2)𝑂superscript𝑀2O(M^{2}) to O​(k​M)𝑂𝑘𝑀O(kM), where k≪Mmuch-less-than𝑘𝑀k\ll M is the sketch size.

Several Newton-type federated algorithms have been proposed to overcome the slow convergence of gradient-based methods in FL. Distributed Newton [24] and Local Newton [25] replace SGD with Newton’s method on local machines, accelerating convergence for local models. FedNew [26] introduced a one-pass ADMM to calculate local directions, while an approximate Newton method is used to update the global model. FedNL [27] sends compressed local Hessian updates to the global server to perform a global Newton step, reducing the communication overhead. Additionally, SHED [28] uses eigendecomposition of local Hessian matrices, incrementally updating eigenvector-eigenvalue pairs to the global server to recover the Hessian for performing Newton’s method globally.

In this paper, we propose FLeNS, which builds on these developments by extending Newton Sketch to FL. Our methods achieve super-linear convergence with a communication complexity of O​(k​M)𝑂𝑘𝑀O(kM), where k𝑘k is the effective dimension of the Hessian. By leveraging techniques like Nesterov-Newton Sketch, we minimize communication rounds while maintaining the fast convergence properties of Newton’s methods.

III Background

A standard federated learning (FL) system consists of a global server and m𝑚m local nodes, each with its dataset Dj={(xi​j,yi​j)}i=1njsubscript𝐷𝑗superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑗D_{j}=\{(x_{ij},y_{ij})\}_{i=1}^{n_{j}}, where ∀j∈[m]for-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑚\forall j\in[m], the data is drawn from a local distribution ρjsubscript𝜌𝑗\rho_{j} on X×Y𝑋𝑌X\times Y, with X𝑋X as the input space and Y𝑌Y as the output space. The union of all local datasets forms the global dataset D=⋃j=1mDj𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝐷𝑗D=\bigcup_{j=1}^{m}D_{j}, which follows a global distribution ρ𝜌\rho on X×Y𝑋𝑌X\times Y. The key objective of FL is to train a global model without sharing local data for privacy and communication efficiency. Ideally, the model would be trained on the entire dataset D𝐷D, but in practice, local data remains decentralized.

The number of examples on each local machine is denoted by nj=|Dj|subscript𝑛𝑗subscript𝐷𝑗n_{j}=|D_{j}|, and the total number of examples is N=∑j=1mnj𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑛𝑗N=\sum_{j=1}^{m}n_{j}. The goal is to train a global model using this decentralized data based on the empirical risk minimization objective.

III-A Centralized Newton’s Method

In centralized settings, the objective is commonly framed as:

wD,λ=arg⁡minw∈ℋK⁡(1N​∑i=1Nℓ​(f​(xi),yi)+λ​α​(w)),subscript𝑤𝐷𝜆subscript𝑤subscriptℋ𝐾1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁ℓ𝑓subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝜆𝛼𝑤w_{D,\lambda}=\arg\min_{w\in\mathcal{H}_{K}}\left(\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\ell(f(x_{i}),y_{i})+\lambda\alpha(w)\right), (1)

where ℓℓ\ell is the loss function, α​(w)𝛼𝑤\alpha(w) is the regularization term, and λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0 is the regularization hyparameter. Here, we assume, f∈ℋK𝑓subscriptℋ𝐾f\in\mathcal{H}_{K} belongs to the reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS). defined by a Mercer kernel K:X×X→ℝ:𝐾→𝑋𝑋ℝK:X\times X\rightarrow\mathbb{R}. This ensures that the model is defined as:

f​(x)=⟨w,ϕ​(x)⟩,𝑓𝑥𝑤italic-ϕ𝑥f(x)=\langle w,\phi(x)\rangle, (2)

where ϕ:𝒳→ℋK:italic-ϕ→𝒳subscriptℋ𝐾\phi:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{H}_{K} is the implicit feature mapping.

For convex and twice-differentiable loss functions, the optimization problem can be solved using the exact Newton method:

wt+1=wt−μ​HD,t−1​gD,t,subscript𝑤𝑡1subscript𝑤𝑡𝜇superscriptsubscript𝐻𝐷𝑡1subscript𝑔𝐷𝑡w_{t+1}=w_{t}-\mu H_{D,t}^{-1}g_{D,t}, (3)

Where μ𝜇\mu is the step size, and the gradient and Hessian at step t𝑡t are:

gD,t:=∇L​(D,wt)+λ​∇α​(wt),assignsubscript𝑔𝐷𝑡∇𝐿𝐷subscript𝑤𝑡𝜆∇𝛼subscript𝑤𝑡g_{D,t}:=\nabla L(D,w_{t})+\lambda\nabla\alpha(w_{t}),
HD,t:=∇2L​(D,wt)+λ​∇2α​(wt).assignsubscript𝐻𝐷𝑡superscript∇2𝐿𝐷subscript𝑤𝑡𝜆superscript∇2𝛼subscript𝑤𝑡H_{D,t}:=\nabla^{2}L(D,w_{t})+\lambda\nabla^{2}\alpha(w_{t}).

In federated learning, the system cannot access local training data directly, making it difficult to compute the global gradient gD,tsubscript𝑔𝐷𝑡g_{D,t} and Hessian matrix HD,tsubscript𝐻𝐷𝑡H_{D,t} accurately. The total time complexity of Newton’s method is O​(N​M2​t)𝑂𝑁superscript𝑀2𝑡O(NM^{2}t), where M𝑀M represents the dimension of the feature space and t𝑡t denotes the number of iterations. Newton’s method achieves a super-linear convergence rate of t=log⁡(log⁡(1/δ))𝑡1𝛿t=\log(\log(1/\delta)) for a δ𝛿\delta-accurate solution [29].

III-B Newton’s Method with Partial Sketching

To improve the computational efficiency, Newton Sketch [19] was introduced. This method constructs a structured random embedding of the Hessian matrix using a sketch matrix S∈ℝk×M𝑆superscriptℝ𝑘𝑀S\in\mathbb{R}^{k\times M}, where k≪Nmuch-less-than𝑘𝑁k\ll N. Partial Newton Sketch [23] improves this by sketching only the loss term while keeping the regularization term exact. The update rule becomes:

wt+1subscript𝑤𝑡1\displaystyle w_{t+1} =wt−μ​H~D,t−1​gD,t,withabsentsubscript𝑤𝑡𝜇superscriptsubscript~𝐻𝐷𝑡1subscript𝑔𝐷𝑡with\displaystyle=w_{t}-\mu\tilde{H}_{D,t}^{-1}g_{D,t},\quad\text{with}
H~D,tsubscript~𝐻𝐷𝑡\displaystyle\tilde{H}_{D,t} =(S​∇2L​(𝒟,wt)1/2)⊤​(S​∇2L​(𝒟,wt)1/2)absentsuperscript𝑆superscript∇2𝐿superscript𝒟subscript𝑤𝑡12top𝑆superscript∇2𝐿superscript𝒟subscript𝑤𝑡12\displaystyle=\left(S\nabla^{2}L(\mathcal{D},w_{t})^{1/2}\right)^{\top}\left(S\nabla^{2}L(\mathcal{D},w_{t})^{1/2}\right)
+λ​∇2α​(wt).𝜆superscript∇2𝛼subscript𝑤𝑡\displaystyle\quad+\lambda\nabla^{2}\alpha(w_{t}). (4)

In this method, S𝑆S is a zero-mean sketch matrix normalized such that 𝔼​[S⊤​S/k]=IM𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑆top𝑆𝑘subscript𝐼𝑀\mathbb{E}[S^{\top}S/k]=I_{M}. Different types of sketches, such as sub-Gaussian embeddings, SRHT [30], and SJLT, offer trade-offs between sketching speed and communication complexity. SRHT achieves O​(N​M​log⁡k)𝑂𝑁𝑀𝑘O(NM\log k) complexity, balancing fast computation and a small sketch size.

In federated settings, various Newton-type federated algorithms have been proposed to reduce communication overhead. Distributed Newton Local Newton [25] applies Newton’s method locally on each machine to speed up local convergence. FedNew [26] uses a one-pass ADMM and an approximate Newton method to update the global model, while FedNL [27] compresses local Hessian updates for efficient communication. SHED [28] leverages the eigendecomposition of local Hessians to reconstruct the global Hessian matrix, further reducing the communication burden.

III-C Federated Newton’s Method (FedNewton)

To achieve an accurate approximation of the global model fD,λsubscript𝑓𝐷𝜆f_{D,\lambda}, federated learning algorithms often rely on exchanging local information between clients. In methods like FedAvg and FedProx, this information typically consists of first-order gradients. However, we propose utilizing both first-order and second-order information to better capture the solution to equation (1) for the entire dataset D𝐷D.

It is important to observe that both the local gradients and Hessians in equation (3) can be aggregated into global gradient and Hessian representations. This motivates the development of the Federated Newton’s Method (FedNewton), which updates the model as follows:

wt+1subscript𝑤𝑡1\displaystyle w_{t+1} =wt−μ​HD,t−1​gD,t,withabsentsubscript𝑤𝑡𝜇superscriptsubscript𝐻𝐷𝑡1subscript𝑔𝐷𝑡with\displaystyle=w_{t}-\mu H_{D,t}^{-1}g_{D,t},\quad\text{with}
HD,tsubscript𝐻𝐷𝑡\displaystyle H_{D,t} =∑j=1mnjN​HDj,t,gD,t=∑j=1mnjN​gDj,t.formulae-sequenceabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑛𝑗𝑁subscript𝐻subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡subscript𝑔𝐷𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑛𝑗𝑁subscript𝑔subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡\displaystyle=\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{n_{j}}{N}H_{D_{j},t},\quad g_{D,t}=\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{n_{j}}{N}g_{D_{j},t}. (5)

Complexity Analysis

Before any iteration begins, computing the feature mapping on a local machine requires O​(nj​M​d)𝑂subscript𝑛𝑗𝑀𝑑O(n_{j}Md) time. For the j𝑗j-th local worker, the time complexity per iteration is at least O​(nj​M2+nj​M)𝑂subscript𝑛𝑗superscript𝑀2subscript𝑛𝑗𝑀O(n_{j}M^{2}+n_{j}M) to compute the local Hessian HDj,tsubscript𝐻subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡H_{D_{j},t} and gradient gDj,tsubscript𝑔subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡g_{D_{j},t}, respectively. Furthermore, summarizing the local Hessians and computing the global inverse Hessian incurs a time complexity of O​(m​M2+M3)𝑂𝑚superscript𝑀2superscript𝑀3O(mM^{2}+M^{3}).

However, the communication cost per iteration is O​(M2)𝑂superscript𝑀2O(M^{2}) due to the need to upload local Hessian matrices, making this approach impractical in many federated learning scenarios. Overall, the total computational complexity is O​(maxj∈[m]⁡nj​M​d+nj​M2​t+M3​t)𝑂subscript𝑗delimited-[]𝑚subscript𝑛𝑗𝑀𝑑subscript𝑛𝑗superscript𝑀2𝑡superscript𝑀3𝑡O(\max_{j\in[m]}n_{j}Md+n_{j}M^{2}t+M^{3}t), and the communication complexity is O​(M2​t)𝑂superscript𝑀2𝑡O(M^{2}t). Newton’s method achieves quadratic convergence with t=O​(log⁡(log⁡(1/δ)))𝑡𝑂1𝛿t=O(\log(\log(1/\delta))) for a δ𝛿\delta-approximation guarantee [29], meaning L​(D,wt)−L​(D,wD,λ)≤δ𝐿𝐷subscript𝑤𝑡𝐿𝐷subscript𝑤𝐷𝜆𝛿L(D,w_{t})-L(D,w_{D,\lambda})\leq\delta, where wD,λsubscript𝑤𝐷𝜆w_{D,\lambda} is the empirical risk minimizer as described in equation (1).

IV Methodology

In this paper, we present FLeNS (Federated Learning with Enhanced Nesterov-Newton Sketch), a novel federated learning algorithm that integrates Nesterov’s accelerated gradient method [20] with Hessian sketching [19] to enhance federated learning efficiency. Each client computes its local gradient and approximates its local Hessian using a sketching technique Subspace Randomized Hadamard Transform (SRHT) [23]. Instead of transmitting full Hessians, clients send these reduced-dimension sketched Hessians and gradients to a central server. The server aggregates the sketched Hessians and gradients to form global approximations. Leveraging Nesterov’s momentum, the server updates the global model parameters using the aggregated data, performing accelerated gradient steps. This methodology reduces communication costs by minimizing transmitted data sizes and accelerates convergence by effectively utilizing second-order information in a compressed form.

Overview of Federated Optimization

Federated learning involves optimizing a global model by distributing the computation across multiple clients, each of which holds a local dataset. The global objective function is to minimize the loss across all clients:

w∗superscript𝑤\displaystyle w^{*} =argminw∈ℝd{L(w)=1N∑j=1m∑i=1njℓ(f(w;xi​j),yi​j)\displaystyle=\arg\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left\{L(w)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{m}\sum_{i=1}^{n_{j}}\ell(f(w;x_{ij}),y_{ij})\right. (6)
+λ2∥w∥2}\displaystyle\quad\left.+\frac{\lambda}{2}\|w\|^{2}\right\}

where N=∑j=1mnj𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑛𝑗N=\sum_{j=1}^{m}n_{j} is the total number of data points across all clients, and ℓ​(f​(w;xi​j),yi​j)ℓ𝑓𝑤subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗\ell(f(w;x_{ij}),y_{ij}) represents the loss function for data point xi​j,yi​jsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗x_{ij},y_{ij}.

Nesterov’s Accelerated Gradient

The first key innovation in FLeNS is the integration of Nesterov’s acceleration at the client level. Nesterov’s method provides an anticipatory momentum update, where the parameter vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t} is computed based on both the current and the previous model states:

vt=wt+βt​(wt−wt−1)subscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝛽𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡1v_{t}=w_{t}+\beta_{t}(w_{t}-w_{t-1}) (7)

Here, βtsubscript𝛽𝑡\beta_{t} is a momentum term that controls the degree of acceleration. This update mechanism reduces the number of iterations required to reach a desired level of accuracy compared to standard gradient descent or Newton’s method without acceleration, resulting in faster convergence rates. FLeNS leverages this accelerated approach to efficiently navigate the optimization landscape.

Hessian Sketching for Communication Efficiency

A major bottleneck in federated learning is the communication overhead between clients and the central server. Second-order methods, while theoretically promising due to their use of curvature information (i.e., the Hessian), typically suffer from high communication costs, scaling as 𝒪​(M2)𝒪superscript𝑀2\mathcal{O}(M^{2}), where M𝑀M is the dimensionality of the model. FLeNS addresses this limitation through Hessian sketching, which reduces the communication complexity by projecting the high-dimensional Hessian into a lower-dimensional space using a sketch matrix Sj∈ℝk×Msubscript𝑆𝑗superscriptℝ𝑘𝑀S_{j}\in\mathbb{R}^{k\times M}, where k≪Mmuch-less-than𝑘𝑀k\ll M:

H~Dj,t=Sj⊤​∇2LDj,t​Sjsubscript~𝐻subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗topsuperscript∇2subscript𝐿subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡subscript𝑆𝑗\tilde{H}_{D_{j},t}=S_{j}^{\top}\nabla^{2}L_{D_{j},t}S_{j} (8)

This reduces the transmission complexity to 𝒪​(k2)𝒪superscript𝑘2\mathcal{O}(k^{2}), significantly improving the scalability of the algorithm. By applying Hessian sketching at each client, FLeNS reduces the amount of data exchanged during communication rounds, making the approach more practical for bandwidth-constrained networks.

Second-Order Information and Momentum Synergy

While first-order methods (e.g., standard gradient descent) rely solely on gradient information for parameter updates, second-order methods utilize the Hessian to capture curvature information, leading to more informed updates. FLeNS maintains the advantages of second-order methods while simultaneously benefiting from the speed of Nesterov’s acceleration. By combining Hessian sketching with Nesterov’s momentum, FLeNS achieves a synergy that enhances the optimization process:

wt+1=wt−μ​H~D,t−1​gD,tsubscript𝑤𝑡1subscript𝑤𝑡𝜇superscriptsubscript~𝐻𝐷𝑡1subscript𝑔𝐷𝑡w_{t+1}=w_{t}-\mu\tilde{H}_{D,t}^{-1}g_{D,t} (9)

where H~D,tsubscript~𝐻𝐷𝑡\tilde{H}_{D,t} is the aggregated sketched Hessian and gD,tsubscript𝑔𝐷𝑡g_{D,t} is the aggregated gradient. This update effectively balances the speed of convergence and the quality of updates, allowing the algorithm to navigate complex, non-convex loss landscapes more efficiently than algorithms relying solely on first-order gradients.

Communication and Aggregation

At each iteration, clients compute their local gradients and sketched Hessians and send these to the central server. The server then aggregates these contributions:

H~D,t=∑j=1mnjN​H~Dj,t+1,gD,t=∑j=1mnjN​gDj,t+1formulae-sequencesubscript~𝐻𝐷𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑛𝑗𝑁subscript~𝐻subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡1subscript𝑔𝐷𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑛𝑗𝑁subscript𝑔subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡1\tilde{H}_{D,t}=\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{n_{j}}{N}\tilde{H}_{D_{j},t+1},\quad g_{D,t}=\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{n_{j}}{N}g_{D_{j},t+1}

This aggregation ensures that the global model update reflects the collective information from all clients, making the optimization process robust to data heterogeneity across different clients.

Computational Complexity

The local gradient computation for njsubscript𝑛𝑗n_{j} data points is O​(nj​M)𝑂subscript𝑛𝑗𝑀O(n_{j}M), where njsubscript𝑛𝑗n_{j} is the number of data points and M𝑀M is the model dimension. Hessian sketching reduces this complexity to O​(k​nj​M+k2​M)𝑂𝑘subscript𝑛𝑗𝑀superscript𝑘2𝑀O(kn_{j}M+k^{2}M), where k≪Mmuch-less-than𝑘𝑀k\ll M is the sketch size. At the server side, the per-iteration complexity involves aggregating the sketched Hessians from m𝑚m clients at O​(m​k2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝑘2O(mk^{2}), gradients at O​(m​k)𝑂𝑚𝑘O(mk), inverting the sketched Hessian at O​(k3)𝑂superscript𝑘3O(k^{3}), and updating the global model at O​(M)𝑂𝑀O(M). Thus, the total computational complexity per iteration is O​(nj​M)𝑂subscript𝑛𝑗𝑀O(n_{j}M) for each client and O​(k3+m​k2+M)𝑂superscript𝑘3𝑚superscript𝑘2𝑀O(k^{3}+mk^{2}+M) at the server.

The communication complexity is minimized by transmitting sketched Hessians and gradients, with the communication cost from each client to the server being O​(k2)𝑂superscript𝑘2O(k^{2}) for the Hessians and O​(k)𝑂𝑘O(k) for the gradients. The server sends back the updated global model at a cost of O​(M)𝑂𝑀O(M), leading to a total communication complexity of O​(k2)𝑂superscript𝑘2O(k^{2}) from the client to the server and O​(M)𝑂𝑀O(M) from the server to each client.

The sketch size k𝑘k is critical for balancing computational efficiency and communication overhead. Choosing k≪Mmuch-less-than𝑘𝑀k\ll M reduces the size of the Hessians, thereby lowering both computational load and communication cost, while maintaining an effective approximation of the Hessian. FLeNS achieves a super-linear convergence rate of t=O​(log⁡log⁡(1/δ))𝑡𝑂1𝛿t=O(\log\log(1/\delta)), where δ𝛿\delta represents the approximation accuracy.

V Theoretical Guarantees

In this section, we provide a detailed computational complexity analysis of the Federated Learning with Enhanced Nesterov-Newton Sketch (FLeNS) algorithm. The analysis is divided into two parts: the computational complexity at the client side and the computational complexity at the server side. Additionally, we examine the communication complexity between clients and the server.

Local Computations at Each Client

Each client j𝑗j performs computations to update local gradients and Hessians, apply Nesterov’s acceleration, and prepare data for communication to the server.

Step 1: Local Gradient Computation

Each client computes the local gradient gDj,tsubscript𝑔subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡g_{D_{j},t} at iteration t𝑡t:

gDj,t=1nj​∑i=1nj∇wℓ​(f​(wt;xi​j),yi​j)+λ​wtsubscript𝑔subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡1subscript𝑛𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑗subscript∇𝑤ℓ𝑓subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗𝜆subscript𝑤𝑡g_{D_{j},t}=\frac{1}{n_{j}}\sum_{i=1}^{n_{j}}\nabla_{w}\ell\left(f\left(w_{t};x_{ij}\right),y_{ij}\right)+\lambda w_{t}

Cost per data point: O​(M)𝑂𝑀O(M) operations per data point, where M𝑀M is the dimension of model w𝑤w. Total cost per client: O​(nj​M)𝑂subscript𝑛𝑗𝑀O(n_{j}M).

Step 2: Hessian Sketching

Each client computes a sketched Hessian using sketch matrix Sj∈ℝk×Msubscript𝑆𝑗superscriptℝ𝑘𝑀S_{j}\in\mathbb{R}^{k\times M}, where k≪Mmuch-less-than𝑘𝑀k\ll M:

H~Dj,t=Sj⊤​∇2LDj,t​Sjsubscript~𝐻subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗topsuperscript∇2subscript𝐿subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡subscript𝑆𝑗\tilde{H}_{D_{j},t}=S_{j}^{\top}\nabla^{2}L_{D_{j},t}S_{j}

Cost per Hessian-vector product: O​(nj​M)𝑂subscript𝑛𝑗𝑀O(n_{j}M) per product. Total cost for k𝑘k Hessian-vector products: O​(k​nj​M)𝑂𝑘subscript𝑛𝑗𝑀O(kn_{j}M). Multiplying with Sj⊤superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗topS_{j}^{\top} requires O​(k2​M)𝑂superscript𝑘2𝑀O(k^{2}M). Total cost for Hessian sketching:

O​(k​nj​M+k2​M)𝑂𝑘subscript𝑛𝑗𝑀superscript𝑘2𝑀O(kn_{j}M+k^{2}M)
Step 3: Nesterov’s Acceleration

Each client updates the momentum term vt=wt+βt​(wt−wt−1)subscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝛽𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡1v_{t}=w_{t}+\beta_{t}\left(w_{t}-w_{t-1}\right), costing O​(M)𝑂𝑀O(M). Total cost per client: O​(nj​M)𝑂subscript𝑛𝑗𝑀O(n_{j}M).

V-1 Global Computations at the Server

The server aggregates sketched Hessians and gradients from all m𝑚m clients:

H~D,t=∑j=1mnjN​H~Dj,t+1,gD,t=∑j=1mnjN​gDj,t+1formulae-sequencesubscript~𝐻𝐷𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑛𝑗𝑁subscript~𝐻subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡1subscript𝑔𝐷𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑛𝑗𝑁subscript𝑔subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡1\tilde{H}_{D,t}=\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{n_{j}}{N}\tilde{H}_{D_{j},t+1},\quad g_{D,t}=\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{n_{j}}{N}g_{D_{j},t+1}

Cost: Aggregating gradients O​(m​k)𝑂𝑚𝑘O(mk), Hessians O​(m​k2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝑘2O(mk^{2}). Inverting H~D,tsubscript~𝐻𝐷𝑡\tilde{H}_{D,t}: O​(k3)𝑂superscript𝑘3O(k^{3}). Global model update: O​(M)𝑂𝑀O(M). Total cost at the server:

O​(k3+m​k2+M)𝑂superscript𝑘3𝑚superscript𝑘2𝑀O(k^{3}+mk^{2}+M)

V-A Communication Complexity

V-A1 From Clients to Server

Clients send sketched Hessian H~Dj,t+1∈ℝk×ksubscript~𝐻subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡1superscriptℝ𝑘𝑘\tilde{H}_{D_{j},t+1}\in\mathbb{R}^{k\times k} and gradient gDj,t+1∈ℝksubscript𝑔subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡1superscriptℝ𝑘g_{D_{j},t+1}\in\mathbb{R}^{k}, costing O​(k2)𝑂superscript𝑘2O(k^{2}) and O​(k)𝑂𝑘O(k), respectively. Total communication: O​(k2)𝑂superscript𝑘2O(k^{2}).

V-A2 From Server to Clients

The server sends the updated model wt+1∈ℝMsubscript𝑤𝑡1superscriptℝ𝑀w_{t+1}\in\mathbb{R}^{M}, costing O​(M)𝑂𝑀O(M).

V-B Overall Complexity Summary

Per Iteration Complexity:

Computational: Per client: O​(nj​M)𝑂subscript𝑛𝑗𝑀O(n_{j}M), Server: O​(k3+m​k2+M)𝑂superscript𝑘3𝑚superscript𝑘2𝑀O(k^{3}+mk^{2}+M). Communication: From each client: O​(k2)𝑂superscript𝑘2O(k^{2}), From server: O​(M)𝑂𝑀O(M).

Total Complexity over T𝑇T Iterations:

Computational: Per client: O​(T​nj​M)𝑂𝑇subscript𝑛𝑗𝑀O(Tn_{j}M), Server: O​(T​(k3+m​k2+M))𝑂𝑇superscript𝑘3𝑚superscript𝑘2𝑀O(T(k^{3}+mk^{2}+M)). Communication: From each client: O​(T​k2)𝑂𝑇superscript𝑘2O(Tk^{2}), To each client: O​(T​M)𝑂𝑇𝑀O(TM).

V-C Convergence Analysis of FLeNS

In this section, we present a detailed convergence analysis of the Federated Learning with Enhanced Nesterov-Newton Sketch (FLeNS) algorithm. We outline the necessary assumptions and derive the convergence properties of the algorithm. The goal is to demonstrate that FLeNS converges to the global optimum under certain conditions, leveraging both Nesterov’s acceleration and Hessian sketching.

Assumptions

To establish the convergence of FLeNS, we make the following standard assumptions:

Assumption A1 (Smoothness of Loss Function):

The loss function ℓ​(f​(w;x),y)ℓ𝑓𝑤𝑥𝑦\ell(f(w;x),y) is twice continuously differentiable with respect to w𝑤w, and its gradient is Lipschitz continuous with constant L1>0subscript𝐿10L_{1}>0:

∀w,vfor-all𝑤𝑣\displaystyle\forall w,v ∈ℝd,∀x,yabsentsuperscriptℝ𝑑for-all𝑥𝑦\displaystyle\in\mathbb{R}^{d},\forall x,y
Assumption A2 (Strong Convexity and Smoothness of Loss Function [19]):

The Hessian ∇w2ℓ​(f​(w;x),y)subscriptsuperscript∇2𝑤ℓ𝑓𝑤𝑥𝑦\nabla^{2}_{w}\ell(f(w;x),y) is Lipschitz continuous with constant L2>0subscript𝐿20L_{2}>0:

The Hessian ∇2L​(w)superscript∇2𝐿𝑤\nabla^{2}L(w) is Lipschitz continuous with constant L2>0subscript𝐿20L_{2}>0:

The sketch matrix Sj∈ℝk×dsubscript𝑆𝑗superscriptℝ𝑘𝑑S_{j}\in\mathbb{R}^{k\times d} satisfies the Subspace Embedding Property for the Hessian:

The momentum parameter βtsubscript𝛽𝑡\beta_{t} is set according to:

βt=L1−γL1+γsubscript𝛽𝑡subscript𝐿1𝛾subscript𝐿1𝛾\beta_{t}=\frac{L_{1}-\gamma}{L_{1}+\gamma}

Convergence Theorem

Theorem 1 (Convergence of FLeNS):

Under Assumptions A1–A7, if the step size μ𝜇\mu is chosen such that 0<μ≤1L10𝜇1subscript𝐿10<\mu\leq\frac{1}{L_{1}}, the sequence {wt}subscript𝑤𝑡\{w_{t}\} generated by FLeNS converges to the global optimum w∗superscript𝑤w^{*}. Specifically, the convergence rate is given by:

L​(wt)−L​(w∗)≤(11+κ)2​t​(L​(w0)−L​(w∗))𝐿subscript𝑤𝑡𝐿superscript𝑤superscript11𝜅2𝑡𝐿subscript𝑤0𝐿superscript𝑤L(w_{t})-L(w^{*})\leq\left(\frac{1}{1+\kappa}\right)^{2t}(L(w_{0})-L(w^{*}))

where κ=L1γ𝜅subscript𝐿1𝛾\kappa=\frac{L_{1}}{\gamma} is the condition number of the objective function.

Interpretation:

  • •

    The algorithm achieves a convergence rate of O​((11+κ)2​t)𝑂superscript11𝜅2𝑡O\left(\left(\frac{1}{1+\kappa}\right)^{2t}\right), which is faster than the standard gradient descent rate O​((1−1κ)t)𝑂superscript11𝜅𝑡O\left(\left(1-\frac{1}{\kappa}\right)^{t}\right) and matches the accelerated gradient methods.

  • •

    The incorporation of Nesterov’s acceleration and second-order information via Hessian sketching leads to an improved convergence rate.

Proof of Theorem 1

The proof follows the standard analysis of Nesterov’s method combined with the sketching procedure. The steps are outlined below:

Step 1: Preliminaries

Let et=wt−w∗subscript𝑒𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡superscript𝑤e_{t}=w_{t}-w^{*} denote the error vector at iteration t𝑡t. From the strong convexity of L​(w)𝐿𝑤L(w) (Assumption A2), we get:

L​(wt)−L​(w∗)≥γ2​‖et‖2𝐿subscript𝑤𝑡𝐿superscript𝑤𝛾2superscriptnormsubscript𝑒𝑡2L(w_{t})-L(w^{*})\geq\frac{\gamma}{2}\|e_{t}\|^{2}
Step 2: Update Equations

The FLeNS algorithm updates are:

vt=wt+βt​(wt−wt−1),wt+1=wt−μ​H~D,t+1−1​gD,t+1formulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝛽𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡1subscript𝑤𝑡1subscript𝑤𝑡𝜇superscriptsubscript~𝐻𝐷𝑡11subscript𝑔𝐷𝑡1v_{t}=w_{t}+\beta_{t}(w_{t}-w_{t-1}),\quad w_{t+1}=w_{t}-\mu\tilde{H}_{D,t+1}^{-1}g_{D,t+1}
Step 3: Error Recursion

The error term et+1subscript𝑒𝑡1e_{t+1} is expressed as:

et+1=(1−μ)​et−μ​βt​(et−et−1)subscript𝑒𝑡11𝜇subscript𝑒𝑡𝜇subscript𝛽𝑡subscript𝑒𝑡subscript𝑒𝑡1e_{t+1}=(1-\mu)e_{t}-\mu\beta_{t}(e_{t}-e_{t-1})
Step 4: Using the Hessian Approximation

With the Hessian approximation (Assumption A6), the inverse approximation of the Hessian gives bounds on the error term, leading to the recursive bound:

‖et+1‖≤(1−μ)​‖et‖+μ​βt​(‖et‖+‖et−1‖)normsubscript𝑒𝑡11𝜇normsubscript𝑒𝑡𝜇subscript𝛽𝑡normsubscript𝑒𝑡normsubscript𝑒𝑡1\|e_{t+1}\|\leq(1-\mu)\|e_{t}\|+\mu\beta_{t}(\|e_{t}\|+\|e_{t-1}\|)
Step 5: Solving the Recurrence

This recurrence relation leads to the convergence rate, which is faster than the standard gradient descent and comparable to accelerated gradient methods:

L​(wt)−L​(w∗)≤(11+κ)2​t​(L​(w0)−L​(w∗))𝐿subscript𝑤𝑡𝐿superscript𝑤superscript11𝜅2𝑡𝐿subscript𝑤0𝐿superscript𝑤L(w_{t})-L(w^{*})\leq\left(\frac{1}{1+\kappa}\right)^{2t}(L(w_{0})-L(w^{*}))

V-D Generalization Analysis of FLeNS

Under Assumption G1, LS​(wS∗)≤LS​(w∗)subscript𝐿𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑆subscript𝐿𝑆superscript𝑤L_{S}(w_{S}^{*})\leq L_{S}(w^{*}), so LS​(wS∗)−L​(w∗)≤LS​(w∗)−L​(w∗)subscript𝐿𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑆𝐿superscript𝑤subscript𝐿𝑆superscript𝑤𝐿superscript𝑤L_{S}(w_{S}^{*})-L(w^{*})\leq L_{S}(w^{*})-L(w^{*}).

Bounding the Optimization Error

Theorem 1 (Optimization Error Bound):

Under Assumptions G2 and G3, the optimization error after t𝑡t iterations of FLeNS is bounded by:

LS​(wt)−LS​(wS∗)≤(11+κ)2​t​(LS​(w0)−LS​(wS∗))subscript𝐿𝑆subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝐿𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑆superscript11𝜅2𝑡subscript𝐿𝑆subscript𝑤0subscript𝐿𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑆L_{S}(w_{t})-L_{S}(w_{S}^{*})\leq\left(\frac{1}{1+\kappa}\right)^{2t}\left(L_{S}(w_{0})-L_{S}(w_{S}^{*})\right)

Proof Sketch: The result follows from the convergence analysis of FLeNS, where we have established that the sequence {wt}subscript𝑤𝑡\{w_{t}\} converges to wS∗superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑆w_{S}^{*} at an accelerated rate due to Nesterov’s acceleration. The convergence rate is characterized by the factor (11+κ)2superscript11𝜅2\left(\frac{1}{1+\kappa}\right)^{2}, leading to the exponential decay of the optimization error.

Bounding the Generalization Error

Lemma 1 (Generalization Error of Empirical Minimizer):

Under Assumptions G1–G4, with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, the following holds:

L​(wS∗)−L​(w∗)≤2​G2γ​N+G2​log⁡(1/δ)N𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑆𝐿superscript𝑤2superscript𝐺2𝛾𝑁superscript𝐺21𝛿𝑁L(w_{S}^{*})-L(w^{*})\leq\frac{2G^{2}}{\gamma N}+\frac{G^{2}\log(1/\delta)}{N}
Lemma 2 (Generalization Error of Model at Iteration t𝑡t):

L​(wt)−LS​(wt)≤G2​log⁡(1/δ)N𝐿subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝐿𝑆subscript𝑤𝑡superscript𝐺21𝛿𝑁L(w_{t})-L_{S}(w_{t})\leq\frac{G^{2}\log(1/\delta)}{N}

Total Excess Risk Bound

Theorem 2 (Total Excess Risk Bound):

Under Assumptions G1–G5, with probability at least 1−2​δ12𝛿1-2\delta, the excess risk of the model wtsubscript𝑤𝑡w_{t} obtained by FLeNS satisfies:

+2​G2​log⁡(1/δ)N2superscript𝐺21𝛿𝑁\displaystyle+\frac{2G^{2}\log(1/\delta)}{N} (11)

VI Compared with Related Work

Table I reports the computational properties of related work to achieve a δ𝛿\delta-accurate solution in terms of the regularized least squares loss. We compare our proposed algorithm FLeNS with first-order methods and other Newton-type federated learning (FL) algorithms.

FedNS applies commonly used sketching approaches, such as sub-Gaussian random projections, SRHT, and Sparse Johnson-Lindenstrauss Transform (SJLT). FLeNS primarily utilizes SRHT due to its favourable computational properties. Different sketch types lead to various sketch times on the j𝑗j-th local machine: O​(nj​M​k)𝑂subscript𝑛𝑗𝑀𝑘O(n_{j}Mk) for Sub-Gaussian, O​(nj​M​log⁡k)𝑂subscript𝑛𝑗𝑀𝑘O(n_{j}M\log k) for SRHT, O​(nnz​(ϕ​(Xj)))𝑂nnzitalic-ϕsubscript𝑋𝑗O(\text{nnz}(\phi(X_{j}))) for SJLT.

Compared with first-order algorithms federated Newton’s methods, including FedNS, FedNDES, and our proposed FLeNS, converge much faster (O​(log⁡1δ)𝑂1𝛿O(\log\frac{1}{\delta}) or O​(log⁡log⁡1δ)𝑂1𝛿O(\log\log\frac{1}{\delta}) vs. O​(1δ)𝑂1𝛿O(\frac{1}{\delta}) for first-order methods like FedAvg and FedProx). However, the communication complexities of federated Newton’s methods are generally higher, at least O​(k​M​t)𝑂𝑘𝑀𝑡O(kMt), while it is O​(M​t)𝑂𝑀𝑡O(Mt) for first-order methods (FedAvg and FedProx).

Compared with Newton-type FL methods Distributed Newton [24] and Local Newton [25] perform Newton’s method using local information and implicitly assume that local datasets across devices are homogeneous, which limits their applicability in federated learning. In contrast, our proposed algorithm communicate local sketched Hessian matrices to approximate the global Hessian, making them naturally applicable to heterogeneous settings.

Recent Newton-Type FL Methods

Several recent Newton-type FL methods include the following: FedNL [27] compresses the difference between the local Hessian and the global Hessian from the previous step and transfers the compressed difference to the global server for merging. Theoretically, FedNL achieves at least linear convergence O​(log⁡1δ)𝑂1𝛿O(\log\frac{1}{\delta}) with a communication cost of O​(M)𝑂𝑀O(M) per round. FedNew [26] uses ADMM to solve an unconstrained convex optimization problem for obtaining the local update directions HDj,t−1​gDj,tsubscript𝐻subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡1subscript𝑔subscript𝐷𝑗𝑡H_{D_{j},t-1}g_{D_{j},t} and performs Newton’s method by averaging these directions at the server. However, this method only proves convergence without explicit convergence rates. SHED [32] performs eigendecomposition on the local Hessian and incrementally sends the eigenvalues and eigenvectors to the server, where the local Hessians are reconstructed to perform Newton’s method, achieving super-linear convergence with a total communication cost of O​(M2)𝑂superscript𝑀2O(M^{2}). FedNS [33] utilizes Hessian sketching to approximate the global Newton step. By communicating sketched Hessians of size k×M𝑘𝑀k\times M from each client to the server, FedNS reduces communication costs compared to transmitting full Hessians. It achieves super-linear convergence rates O​(log⁡log⁡1δ)𝑂1𝛿O(\log\log\frac{1}{\delta}), although the communication per round is O​(k​M)𝑂𝑘𝑀O(kM), which can still be significant if k𝑘k is large. FedNDES [33] improves upon FedNS by using dimension-efficient sketching and adaptive strategies to further reduce the sketch size k𝑘k to d~λsubscript~𝑑𝜆\tilde{d}_{\lambda}, the empirical effective dimension of the data, resulting in lower communication costs per round O​(k​M)𝑂𝑘𝑀O(kM) while maintaining the super-linear convergence rate O​(log⁡log⁡1δ)𝑂1𝛿O(\log\log\frac{1}{\delta}).

FLeNS (our proposed algorithm): Further advances the state-of-the-art by integrating Nesterov’s acceleration with Leveraging dimension-efficient Hessian sketching and a smaller sketch size k𝑘k. FLeNS achieves accelerated convergence rates while significantly reducing the communication per round to O​(k2)𝑂superscript𝑘2O(k^{2}), thanks to the smaller sketch size and the efficient combination of momentum and second-order information.

VII Experiments

In this section, we conduct experiments to validate our theoretical claims using several real-world federated datasets. Our implementations are based on publicly available code from FedNew [26] and FedNL [27]. However, we excluded the SHED algorithm due to the unavailability of public code [32]. The base model for all methods is logistic regression, and the algorithms update the Hessian matrix at each iteration.

We begin by analyzing the effect of sketch size on the proposed FLeNS algorithm, followed by comparing related methods in terms of communication rounds. As in FedNew [26], we consider regularized logistic regression with the loss function L​(D,w)=1N​∑i=1Nlog⁡(1+exp⁡(−yi​xi⊤​w))+λ​‖w‖22𝐿𝐷𝑤1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁1subscript𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖top𝑤𝜆subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑤22L(D,w)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\log(1+\exp(-y_{i}x_{i}^{\top}w))+\lambda\|w\|^{2}_{2}, where λ𝜆\lambda is the regularization parameter, set to 10−3superscript10310^{-3} for all experiments. Each experiment was conducted 10 times, and the results were averaged. The figures 1, 2, and 3 represent the mean performance. We use the optimality gap, L​(wt)−L​(w∗)𝐿subscript𝑤𝑡𝐿superscript𝑤L(w_{t})-L(w^{*}), as the primary performance metric, with w∗superscript𝑤w^{*} being the solution estimated by global Newton’s method.

The algorithms were evaluated using publicly available LIBSVM datasets [36]. The dataset statistics and relevant hyperparameters are summarized in Table II. In particular, the hyperparameters ρ𝜌\rho and α𝛼\alpha are used in the FedNew algorithm.

VIII Results and Discussions

Convergence comparison.

Figure 1 shows the loss discrepancy (the difference between the loss of the trained model and the optimal solution) over the number of communication rounds for various methods reporting the convergence of the compared methods, and highlighting several key findings. 1) There are significant gaps between the convergence speeds of the proposed method, FLeNS, and existing Newton-type federated learning (FL) methods such as FedNS, FedNDES, FedNew, FedNL, and FedAvg. These gaps validate the accelerated super-linear convergence of FLeNS over other methods. 2) FLeNS converges faster than both FedNS and FedNDES, approaching the performance of FedNewton while requiring less communication and computation. In contrast, FedNew and FedNL converge more slowly, closely resembling the behaviour of FedAvg. 3) Since a lower loss generally correlates with higher predictive accuracy on the test set, we can conclude that FLeNS results in better final predictive accuracy. Despite small sketch sizes, FLeNS demonstrates robustness by maintaining considerable accuracy, making it suitable for scenarios with limited computational resources. 4) FLeNS communicates sketched Hessians of size k×k𝑘𝑘k\times k, denoted as O​(d~​λ2)𝑂~𝑑superscript𝜆2O(\tilde{d}\lambda^{2}), significantly reducing per-round communication compared to methods like FedNS and FedNDES. Additionally, Nesterov’s acceleration allows FLeNS to converge faster, meaning it requires fewer iterations to achieve the desired accuracy. By combining lower per-round communication costs with fewer communication rounds, FLeNS results in the lowest total communication cost among the three methods.

Impact of sketch size on Performance.

Figure 2 reports the results of predictive accuracy as a function of sketch size and highlights several important observations: 1) Increasing the sketch size consistently improves generalization performance. 2) FLeNS algorithms eventually converge towards the global Newton’s method. 3) Even with a small sketch size, i.e., k≪Mmuch-less-than𝑘𝑀k\ll M and k≪Nmuch-less-than𝑘𝑁k\ll N, the performance remains strong.

Impact of sketch size on Computational Time.

Figure 3 shows that FLeNS is significantly more efficient in terms of computational time compared to other methods like FedNS and FedNDES, particularly as the sketch size increases. The plot demonstrates the advantage of using FLeNS, especially when dealing with large sketch sizes, as it maintains low computation time while the other methods experience higher and more variable times.

Conclusion

In this paper, we introduced FLeNS (Federated Learning with Enhanced Nesterov-Newton Sketch), a highly efficient and scalable optimization framework that addresses the inherent limitations of both first-order methods and traditional Newton-type algorithms in federated learning. By integrating Nesterov’s acceleration with dimension-efficient Hessian sketching, FLeNS harnesses the power of second-order information while significantly reducing communication overhead. This novel combination enables FLeNS to achieve super-linear convergence rates, surpassing existing federated Newton-type algorithms such as FedNS, FedNew, and FedNDES.

Unlike conventional methods that require transmitting full Hessian matrices, FLeNS reduces the dimensionality of the Hessian, striking an optimal balance between computational efficiency and communication cost. Its robustness in bandwidth-constrained and privacy-sensitive environments further demonstrates its adaptability, making it a versatile solution across a diverse range of federated learning applications. Furthermore, FLeNS excels at balancing key trade-offs between sketch size, communication efficiency, and convergence speed, reinforcing its practical utility in real-world scenarios where both communication constraints and data heterogeneity are prominent challenges.
